Scouting and proper identification are necessary to determine the need for control of caterpillars in strawberries; broad spectrum caterpillar control materials can affect natural enemy populations and result in pest resurgence and secondary pest problems.

Leafhoppers: Also known as sharpshooters, these insects are slender, elongate insects with round or pointed heads. The forewings are slightly thickened and frequently are held roof-like over the abdomen. Leafhoppers are abundant insects and they are very strong fliers and readily move in and out of orchards.

Damage: Feeding on leaves by nymphs and adults can result in pale yellow spots or stippling. The more important issue is that leafhoppers can vector the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, which causes phony peach disease. Infected trees are more compact, leafier, and darker green than normal trees because of short-internodes. The number and size of fruit are drastically reduced.

Insecticides: Because of the leafhoppers’ mobility, broad host ranges, and abundance on a variety of host plants, currently insecticidal control is impractical as a means of suppressing spread of phony peach disease.

Aphids are commonly found on strawberries but rarely cause economic damage. Many times they are found prior to fruiting; natural enemies will usually keep populations below damaging levels without the use of insecticides. Aphids feed on the undersides of leaves where spider mites are also found; however aphids are much larger than mites. High nitrogen levels are attractive to aphids and can cause an infestation. Aphid feeding results in honeydew build-up on leaves and the plastic mulch.

Several species of aphids will feed on strawberries, but the strawberry aphid is the most dangerous. It is a vector of several serious strawberry virus diseases. It has been introduced to the southeast but has not been shown to persist after introduction. It can be easily distinguished from other aphids found on strawberry due to the knobbed 'hairs' found on its body.

The brown marmorated stink bug (BMSB), Halyomorpha halys, is causing damage to fruit, vegetables and field crops. BMSB overwinters inside houses and other dwellings.

Description and life cycle. BMSB has one to two generations. Overwintering adults emerge in early spring to mid-June and immediately move to feed on available hosts. Feeding on fruit can result in misshapen fruit and formation of necrotic tissue (corking) close to the skin surface, similar to a physiological disorder called bitter pit “corking” caused by calcium deficiency.

Monitoring and management. Pheromone traps and visual observations are the most accurate methods to monitor BMSB. While insecticides are the most effective tool against this pest, the continuous influx of new BMSB adults and nymphs from surrounding areas often warrants necessity for repeated applications thorough the season.

Codling moth (CM) Cydia pomonella, is one of the most important internally feeding larvae impacting apples. Damage to apples usually is shown as a tunnel emanating from the apple side or calyx and extending to the core.

Description and life cycle. The adult female moth is approximately 3∕8 inch long and grayish in color. The male moth is slightly smaller and has a grouping of hair-like scales near the wing base. Codling moth overwinters as full-grown larvae, with first adult flight occurring about full bloom on apples. The second generation adults are active in late July and August. Some larvae of the second generation may pupate and produce a partial third generation.

Monitoring and management. Pheromone traps for codling moths should be used to determine if and when controls are necessary. In orchards without CM mating disruption, the action threshold of five moths per trap per week is used to decide about the necessity of insecticide application. Mating disruption represents very effecfive alternative to insecticide treatment for codling moth management.

Oriental Fruit Moth (OFM): Grapholita molesta (Busck), is an invasive pest of peaches. Moths are grayish, with darker banding on a mottled background. They are roughly 1/4 -inch in length, and have a wingspan of nearly 1/2-inch. Mature larvae are 1/2-inch long, pinkish in color, brown-headed, with three pairs of true legs, and numerous fleshy prolegs along the abdomen.

Damage: OFM larvae tunnel into succulent vegetative shoot growth as well as the fruit. Feeding on shoots kills the tip of the shoot, causing shoot strikes or ‘flagging’, where the terminal begins to droop and discolor as it dies. The most severe damage occurs where larvae bore to the center of the fruit and feed around the pit, resulting in unmarketable fruit.

Insecticides: OFM is controlled in the orchard through the use of organophosphates (phosmet; Imidan) or pyrethroids (beta cyfluthrin, cyfluthrin, gamma and lambda cyhalothrin, etc.) aimed to manage the first generation.

Oriental Fruit Moth (OFM): Grapholita molesta (Busck), is an invasive pest of apples. Moths are grayish, with darker banding on a mottled background. They are roughly 1/4 -inch in length, and have a wingspan of nearly 1/2-inch. Mature larvae are 1/2-inch long, pinkish in color, brown-headed, with three pairs of true legs, and numerous fleshy prolegs along the abdomen.

Damage: OFM larvae tunnel into succulent vegetative shoot growth as well as the fruit. Feeding on shoots kills the tip of the shoot, causing shoot strikes or ‘flagging’, where the terminal begins to droop and discolor as it dies. The most severe damage occurs where larvae bore to the center of the fruit and feed around the core, resulting in unmarketable fruit.

Insecticides: OFM is controlled in the orchard through the use of organophosphates (phosmet; Imidan) or pyrethroids (beta cyfluthrin, cyfluthrin, gamma and lambda cyhalothrin, etc.) aimed to manage the first generation.
Measles are bad

Plum curculio (PC) has time and again been identified by pome fruit growers as one of the single most destructive insect pests in the orchard. There are four types of wounds caused by PC, however, oviposition is the most recognizable of these. When the female lays her eggs, she sweeps her ovipositor in an arc along the surface of the fruit. This motion causes the distinctive “half moon” scar. When an egg hatches the larvae tunnel into fruitlets begin to feed, the fruitlet will generally drop to the ground prematurely. When the egg is not viable, or the female decides that she does not want to lay an egg on a particular fruit, the scar remains and can be seen at harvest, often making the fruit unmarketable.

Description and life cycle
Plum curculio is a snout nosed beetle, aka a weevil. The adult is small, about 6 mm, mottled black, grey and brown. When handled it will often “play dead” in an attempt to fool animals that might prey on it. Or any growers lurking about the orchard. The larvae is a whitish, legless grub, its feeding on the inside of fruitlets is what will cause premature drop. Larvae then crawl out of the fallen fruitlets into the soil where they pupate. Adults emerge from the soil after ~16 days. They then kick around, feeding here and there, until cold weather drives them into hibernating spots. Commercial orchards, generally, do not have overwintering populations within their borders. Wild hosts (abandoned orchards, crab apples, etc.) surrounding orchards, on the other hand, are a literal breeding ground for these nasty little buggers. These outsiders will migrate into your orchards right at petal fall, when temperature and moisture are optimal.   

Monitoring and management
While there is promising work with beneficial nematodes underway, management of plum curculio relies heavily on petal fall, first and second cover insecticidal applications.  The first insecticide application should be made to the whole orchard in order to clean up any PC that have migrated into the inner part of the orchard.  Fruitlets should be monitored along orchard borders to determine if new injury is occuring.  If fresh oviposition scars are observed, a first cover border spray should be made.  Cool wet weather will prolong PC activity.  Continue to monitor for fresh scars.  If more are found, a second cover spray may be needed.

Twospotted spider mite is a secondary (non-fruit damage) pest of apple and pear. It is widespread in range, has multiple generations per season, easily develops resistance to miticides, and is particularly problematic when it is dry and moves from the ground cover into fruit trees.

Description and life cycle
Adults are pale yellow to dark green, brownish, or faintly orange. Males are smaller than females, have a distinctly pointed abdomen, and darkish areas on each side of the body. Females are more oval, and when newly hatched have namesake distinct dark areas on each side of the body, which becomes more blotchy and irregular when feeding commences. Nymphs also have distinct two spots. TSSM overwinters under bark or in the ground cover. In spring they typically move to weeds and grass where they feed. In summer they crawl into the canopy especially when it gets dry or the orchard floor is mowed. Once in the tree a serious infestation can develop and cause damage which is grayish bronzing of foliage in apple and solid dark-brown spotting of pear leaves.

Monitoring and management
Check foliage for mite presence beginning in early summer. 10 leaves from 10 trees should be averaged for a count, Chemical treatment is advised if there are six or more mites per leaf. Also check foliage touching ground cover on lower limbs. Summer oil sprays are advised, but a spring oil spray is not effective on TSSM because – unlike European red mite -- they are in the groundcover. If miticides are necessary, only use if over threshold and rotate chemistries for resistance management. If you can identify mite predators, then one predator per leaf on average may justify holding off on applying a miticide. (See http://www.ipm.msu.edu/insects/twospotted_spider_mite for help.)

Adapted from ‘Common Tree Fruit Pests,’ Angus Howitt, Michigan State University, 1993.

Pear pyslla is one of the more problematic insect pests of pear. It is widely distributed, has several generations and life stages, has an unusual ability to rapidly develop chemical control resistance, and where left unchecked, secretes copious amounts of honeydew that grows a black fungus making fruit unmarketable. Heavy infestation can also result in early defoliation,  tree stunting (psylla shock), reduced fruit set and size, and even death with prolonged infestation.

Description and life cycle
Adults are dark red-brown in color, with four wings folded like a pup tent over the back.  They resemble very small cicadas.  Nymphs have five stages, beginning as yellow wingless 3 mm. long when newly hatched, turning darker, and then finally with fifth-instar have wing pads. Adults overwinter in bark crevices and under bark, emerging in the early spring on sunny days when temperature rises above 50 degrees F. Most eggs are laid by bud break. Eggs hatch by petal fall and nymphs move to axils of leaf petioles and stems. They suck on sap which is changed to honeydew and given off as droplets which surround the nymph. Nymphs go through five immature stages and there are at least three generations per season!

Monitoring and management
Look for pear psylla adults on the first nice sunny day of spring before bud break. They can also be monitored using yellow sticky traps. Oil sprays, which deter egg laying, are the first line of defense. Multiple oil sprays may be necessary. After that, choose an effective insecticide, however, realize insecticide sprays are targeting early nymph stages, before they darken, indicating a thickening of the protective outer layer.  Older nymphs become increasingly difficult to manage.  Also, psylla may become resistant to pesticides if overused. Surround is also an option. Focus on early season management. The summer treatment threshold for pear psylla is one psylla nymph/three leaves. Pruning water sprouts in the summer can help dull infestation as the nymphs find it difficult to feed on hardened-off foliage. For an excellent discussion on pear psylla management, see The Jentsch Lab: https://blogs.cornell.edu/jentsch/?s=psylla.

Adapted from ‘Common Tree Fruit Pests,’ Angus Howitt, Michigan State University, 1993.

Speckled green fruitworm is one several members of the Noctuidae fruitworms family which cause damage to fruit and foliage of pome and stone fruit. It was introduced from Europe, the adult being a nocturnal moth, however, it is the larval stage, particularly the large ones that cause unacceptable damage to fruit.

Description and life cycle
Green fruitworm overwinters as an adult moth which starts flying (at night) and lays eggs in the spring. Larvae hatch and go through six instars, the later instars being a quite large (one inch) green caterpillar with yellow/white longitudinal stripes. Larvae feed on flowers, fruit and foliage where they can roll leaves similar to true leafrollers. Individual fruitworm larvae can feed on many fruitlets during the post-bloom period, however, many of these damaged fruits will fall off. Fruit that persists to harvest will have deep corky scars and indentations, which is also similar to leafroller feeding from the overwintering generation.

Monitoring and management
Examine 20 flower/fruit clusters on 5 trees throughout the canopy from pink to first cover. If two or more larvae per tree are found, or there is evidence of feeding damage, treatment is recommended. Pheromone traps can also be deployed to monitor presence and relative abundance of green fruitworms. Pre-bloom insecticides are advised, and pyrethroids are the best choice, however, they can be hard on beneficial insects when applied at this time. Post-bloom insecticide applications targeting other insects are generally effective too. B.t. (Dipel) is effective if applied early before the larvae get too big.

Codling Moth was introduced to North America by European settlers and has since become an established pest in all pear producing regions of the United States and Canada. Larvae cause two types of fruit damage; deep entry, where larvae burrow down into the core of the fruit, pushing frass out as they go and shallow entry where feeding may also occur but no tunneling is present. Both forms of damage render fruit unmarketable.  Second generation larvae cause the most damage.    
 
Description and life cycle
The adult codling moth is gray-brown with alternating lighter gray and white bands across the wings. The wings are marked at the back end  by a coppery area that helps distinguish codling moth from other similar moths. Newly hatched larvae are small, the black head is twice the width of its pale yellow body at this stage. Mature larvae are pinkish-white with a brown head. Codling moth overwinters as a later stage larva. Pupation occurs during bloom. First adults emerge at 150DD, base 50℉, when counting from January 1. Warmer spring temperatures can accelerate growth of codling moth, leading to earlier developmental milestones (like egg laying and hatching). Females can lay up to 100 eggs. Early season eggs are generally laid on leaves whereas later generations are usually laid on fruit. There can be anywhere from one to four generations.

Monitoring and management
Pheromone traps should be hung at bloom, on the north side of the tree at eye level. Hang traps in the orchard where moths are most likely to enter from alternate host sites. Check traps at least once weekly. First insecticide applications should be made ~ 250DD (base 50) after sustained catches in pheromone traps. First insecticide applications for second generation should be made at about 1,400 DD to 1,600 DD, using the same biofix as previous spray timing.

Stink Bugs: (Family Pentatomidae), stink bugs feed on peaches, other stone fruit, and a wide array of wild and cultivated plants, including numerous horticultural and agronomic crops. These hemipterous (sucking) bugs are significant pests throughout the United States. 

Damage: Feeding on leaf buds, flower buds, and blooms can cause the buds to wither and abort, failing to bloom. When feeding on young fruit, the cells in the tissue surrounding the wound are destroyed. This causes scarring, which leads to ‘cat-facing’ injury as the fruit continues to grow and swell. After pit hardening, most stink bug feeding doesn’t cause much scarring or distortion – but the fruit around feeding sites can become dry, corky, and/or slightly sunken areas in the peach

Insecticides: Applications of neonicotinoids (thiamethoxamor clothianidin; e.g. Actara or Belay) mixed with pyrethroids (beta-cyfluthrinor or fenpropathrin; e.g. Baythroid or Danitol) beginning at shuck split is the most effective remedy. Additional applications after that initial treatment can be applied at 10 to 14-day intervals, if stink bug pressure warrants such action.

Plant Bugs: (Family Pentatomidae), plant bugs, particularly the tarnished plant bug, feed on peaches, other stone fruit, and a wide array of wild and cultivated plants, including numerous horticultural and agronomic crops. These hemipterous (sucking) bugs are significant pests throughout the United States. 

Damage: Feeding on leaf buds, flower buds, and blooms can cause the buds to wither and abort, failing to bloom. When feeding on young fruit, the cells in the tissue surrounding the wound are destroyed. This causes scarring, which leads to ‘cat-facing’ injury as the fruit continues to grow and swell. After pit hardening, most stink bug feeding doesn’t cause much scarring or distortion – but the fruit around feeding sites can become dry, corky, and/or slightly sunken areas in the peach.

Insecticides:Applications of neonicotinoids (thiamethoxamor clothianidin; e.g. Actara or Belay) mixed with pyrethroids (beta-cyfluthrinor fenpropathrin; e.g. Baythroid or Danitol) beginning at shuck split is the most effective remedy.

Overview: The black pecan aphid, Melanocalis caryaefoliae (Davis), is the only black plant louse that attacks pecan foliage. Nymphs and adults feed on both sides of the leaves. Their damage is undeniable because they often cause severe leaf shedding in the summer. This species rarely does not become as abundant as the yellow aphid species and unlike the yellow aphids, they do not produce honeydew.
 
Damage: Black pecan aphids may cause damage as early as May but are usually a serious problem
only in late season. Damage appears as yellow spots on leaflets. Damaged spots later
turn brown and 2-4 damaged spots per leaflet can cause leaflet drop. High numbers of black pecan aphids can cause severe defoliation during the late summer and early fall if left unmanaged.
 
Control: The use of an insecticide is the primary method used by growers to control the black pecan aphid. Monitoring is important to know when to spray for this pest. Carefully check all compound leaves on 10 terminals per tree, on at least 10 trees per orchard for the presence of black pecan aphids. Prior to July 1, treat if 25% of terminals have 2 or more black aphids. After July 1, treat if 15% of terminals have more than one black aphid and nymph clusters are found. Concentrate checks on susceptible cultivars such as Schley, Sumner and Gloria Grande. Be sure to check all compound leaves on each terminal examined.

Damage Prevention:
Gibberellic acid is a plant growth regulator that prevents damage from black pecan aphid feeding and inhibits establishment in the orchard. It does not affect aphids directly and will not control any other pest, including yellow aphids. Three applications should be made at 2-week intervals, beginning in mid-July, applying 10 oz (or 5 oz of ProGibb LV Plus) each time.

Overview: The yellow pecan aphids, Monelliopsis pecanis (Bissel), are the smaller of the two yellow-colored aphid species that feed on the underside of pecan foliage. They feed by sucking sap from the veins of the leaves and then excrete large quantities of sticky honeydew.
Description: Nymphs, winged females, and males are pale to bright yellow, have red eyes and are somewhat bullet-shaped.  The major difference between this aphid and the blackmargined aphid is its smaller size. Winged females at rest hold their wings gable-like above the body and measure about 0.1 inch (2.5 mm) in length (including the wings). The cornicles of this species are reduced to pores.
 
Damage: The yellow pecan aphids damage pecans by destroying the vascular system of the leaves where they feed and by the production of honeydew which coats the leaves and acts as a medium for the growth of sooty mold fungus. Feeding also causes a loss in the development of chlorophyll and decrease in the size of leaves in the field. Large populations may cause shedding of basal leaflets in the summer. 
 
Control: To delay the outbreak of yellow pecan aphids growers should never indiscriminately apply pesticides to pecans, particularly in early and mid-season. DO NOT treat yellow aphids if they are the only insect problem. Rely on beneficial insects to suppress early season populations. It is suggested that pyrethroid materials (cypermethrin, bifenthrin, etc.) not be used, alone or in combination, in early- or mid-season applications. In late season, weekly scouting is important in timing aphid sprays. Rotate among classes of insecticides between treatments to avoid resistance development.

Black rot of grape is a potentially devastating disease that can affect the leaves, shoots, berries, and rachis. This disease typically occurs in warm, humid climates.

The fungus, Guignardia bidwellii, can overwinter within infected canes and fruit mumies. Under spring conditions, spores are explosively released into the air and land on susceptible plant tissues. An extended period of leaf wetness and moderate temperatures are required for spores to germinate and infect berries.

Leaf lesions generally apear as circular, tan lesions with a dark perimiter. Black, spherical spore structures called pycnidia speckle the surface within the lesion perimiter. Infections on fruit do not appear until late in the season, turning fruit brown to black with pycnidia dotting the fruit surface.

Sanitation of infected tissue can greatly reduce the inoculum in the field for the following season. Effective fungicides applied at proper timing are key to successful control.

Plum curculio: Conotrachelus nenuphar (Herbst), is a key insect pest of pome and stone fruit in eastern and central North America. Adults are small, about 1/4 inch (4-6 mm) long, brownish-black snout beetles, mottled with lighter gray or brown markings. Their backs are roughened and bear two prominent humps and two smaller humps. Larvae are yellowish-white, legless, brown-headed grubs, about 3/8 inch (6-9 mm) long when fully grown. Larvae are found inside fruit during June and early July.

Damage: Both the adult and larval stages of the plum curculio damage fruit. Most apples infested by plum curculio early in the season drop prematurely.  Adult damage consists of tiny circular feeding punctures or small crescent-shaped oviposition wounds made by females, which cause conspicuous scarring and malformation as the fruit develop. The larvae tunnel and feed in developing fruit. Apples with egg-laying scars that remain on the trees become deformed as they mature, thereby causing important economic losses to growers

Upon reaching orchard trees, plum curculios have shown a tendency to stay in perimeter-row trees but, as the season progresses, plum curculios may move from perimeter-row trees toward interior trees.

Insecticides: Management of plum curculio relies heavily on petal fall, first and second cover insecticide applications. The first insecticide application should be made to the whole orchard in order to control plum curculios that have migrated into the inner part of the orchard. Additional insecticide applications may be necessary and can be limited to the outer two rows of trees. Highly effective insecticides against plum curculio include Imidan 70W, Actara 25WDG, Avaunt 30WDG, Exirel, Voliam Flexi WDG, and Agri-Flex SC. Surround is an organically approved material that can also be complementary to conventional management strategies. Surround applications begin at Petal Fall and get reapplied weekly to maintain coverage and deter egg laying.

For a complete list of insecticides that can be applied against plum curculio, see the New England Tree Fruit Management Guide (https://netreefruit.org). Always follow the label each time you mix and use the pesticide and follow the label when storing or disposing of the pesticide. To avoid chemical resistance, alternate chemicals by IRAC code group.

Alternaria rot is caused by the fungus Alternaria alternata, which is a fungus widespread in nature.
 
Infection is most severe on overripe fruit or where rain-induced cracking or injuries expose flesh to infection.

Cultural control includes removing fruit, mummies and blighted twigs from trees after final harvest, as well as handling fruit carefully at harvest to avoid injuries.

Chemical control includes fungicide sprays prior to harvest.

Thrips: Particularly Western Flower Thrips, are generally minor pests of peaches in the Southeast. Adult thrips are slender, tiny insects (less than 1/12than inch), that can be yellow, brown, or black in color. Thrips have two pairs of wings, made mostly of fringe hairs and they have rasping mouthparts that are used to pierce into plant tissues and ingest sap. Larval thrips look like smaller, wingless adults that tend to be lighter in color than adults.

Damage:Injury generally happens either during bloom or just before and during harvest. 
During bloom, the adults and larvae feed on flower parts, as well as developing fruitlets beneath the shuck. This early feeding on fruits causes scarring/russeting (shallow brown scares), which expands as the fruit grows and swells.
Right around harvest, adults move from other host plants (usually herbaceous weeds) to the ripening peach fruit. They feed on the surface of the fruit, emptying cell contents, and causes “silvering”. Silvering is a light to colorless stippling on the surface of the fruit. 

Insecticides: Targeted applications for thrips with a carbamate before pink, or a spinosyn during pink ornear harvestmay be needed.

Thrips readily develop resistance to insecticides. Spray only as-needed, and alternate MOA #/classes.

Overview: The pecan weevil, Curculio caryae (Horn), attacks the pecan nut, causing serious crop losses in many areas of the southeastern states and in Texas and Oklahoma.
 
Damage: Pecan weevils cause two kinds of nut damage, depending on the stage of nut development at the time of attack. The first kind of damage is caused by adult weevils feeding on kernels in the water stage, before shell hardening. This injury causes the nuts to shrivel, turn black inside and drop prematurely. This type of infestation may pass unnoticed because other insects and factors can also cause a premature nut drop. Damaged nuts can sometimes be recognized by a tiny dark puncture that extends through the shuck and unhardened shell. Weevil-punctured nuts can sometimes be identified by a tobacco-like stain around the feeding site. Prior to shell hardening, the presence of a larva in the nut indicates damage by some other insect, usually nut curculio or hickory shuckworm. Pecan weevil grubs are not found in nuts with unhardened shells.
     The second kind of damage is caused by weevil grubs or larvae, feeding in the partially matured nuts. Damaged mature nuts bleed little and do not drop.  The grubs feed on the kernels for several weeks, destroying the interior of the nut. Infested nuts can be recognized by circular emergence holes about 0.13 inch (3 mm) in diameter through which mature grubs escaped.  Infested nuts are worthless since the larvae normally destroy the kernels, and the shucks often adhere to the shell. The damage is noticeable at harvest time and may destroy practically the entire crop in seasons when large numbers of weevils are present. 
 
Control: Pecan weevil emergence may extend from July into October. Peak emergence is normally between August 10 and September 20. Emergence should be monitored in each infested grove with survey traps (Circle or Tedder’s traps). Trees known to have a recent history of weevil problems should be selected for monitoring. If excessive nut drop results from pecan weevil feeding punctures before pecan shells begin to harden, spray at once. After pecan shells harden and nuts reach the “dough” or “gel” stage, treat when weevils emerge (especially following rains) and continue at 7-10 day intervals until emergence stops.

NOTE: Several pyrethroids, (Asana, Ammo, Baythroid, Brigade, Mustang Max) as well as Imidan are labeled for pecan weevil control. If these materials are used for weevils, they can be expected to be most effective where weevil populations are low. They may be adequate to prevent feeding injury from weevils emerging prior to shell hardening but their use could be risky under heavy weevil pressure after nuts reach the gel stage and are subject to weevil oviposition.

Brown maromorated stink bug (BMSB) is a singularly destructive invasive insect that feeds insatiably on fruits, vegetables adn wild hosts. This insect was first identfied in the USA in Allentown, PA in 1990.  Its population range quickly spread to surrounding states and most notably burst onto the scene as an agricultural pest in the mid-Atlantic causing $37 million in damage to apples alone.

Description and life cycle In the fall BMSB moves into homes, sheds and other man made structures to overwinter.  In the spring, aduts emerge and after about two weeks begin to mate and lay eggs.  Two to three generations are possible in a season, depending on region.  Damage occurs when BMSB feeds on fruit, sucking juices out and leaving behind corked spots beneath the skin of the fuits.  Thier piercing sucking mouth parts can penetrate had shells as well as soft skins.

Monitoring and Management There are several types of traps that are used to monitor BMSB: tedders traps, also known as pyramid traps (pictured in photo gallery) consist of plywood, or corrugated plastic boards placed together to form a base the bugs crawl up and have a container placed on top to cellct them.  Additional traps include clear plastic sticky sheets and rocket traps. Aggregation pheromone lures are used to draw BMSB into traps.  There is no economic threshold for pear at this time.  A provisional threshold of ten BMSB in traps is used in apple.  Damage on fruit is not a viable management decision making threshold as once fruit is damaed, its too late to deal with that wave of pests, instead, scout the perimiter of the orchard, focusing higher up in the canopy to determine pest presence. Effective insecticidal materials targeted at the nymphal stages are best for managing this pest.

The brown marmorated stink bug (BMSB), Halyomorpha halys, is an exotic and invasive stink bug that can cause major damage to tree fruit, especially peaches. BMSB has a "shield" shaped body that is characteristic of all stink bugs. The adults are approximately 5/8 inch long with a mottled brownish grey color. The next to last (4th) antennal segment has a white band and there are black and white bands on several of the abdominal segments. BMSB overwinters inside houses and other dwellings and emerge in early spring, immediately moving to feed on available hosts.
 
Damage: When feeding on young fruit, the cells in the tissue surrounding the wound are destroyed. This causes scarring, which leads to ‘cat-facing’ injury as the fruit continues to grow and swell. After pit hardening, most stink bug feeding doesn’t cause much scarring or distortion – but the fruit around feeding sites can become dry, corky, and/or slightly sunken areas in the peach
 
Insecticides: While insecticides in the neonicotinoid and pyrethroid classes are the most effective tool against this pest, the continuous influx of new BMSB adults and nymphs from surrounding areas often warrants necessity for repeated applications thorough the season.
Mr Hu
Phony peach is caused by the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa.
Phony peach is particularly problematic in the Coastal Plain regions of the Southeast.
The bacterium, X. fastidiosa, survives in the plant xylem from year to year, particularly in the roots.
Bacteria are vectored by sharpshooter insects, and this is the predominant means of spread and epidemic development.
The disease causes stunted trees with shortened internodes, resulting in reduced fruit size and number and eventual premature tree death.

Roguing (destruction) of symptomatic peach trees is the only recommended practice at this time for disease prevention, though identification of infected trees may be difficult in the early stages of disease development.  Removal/destruction of wild plums that are near peach orchards is also recommended. A good weed management program may help through reducing vector habitat and alternative hosts for bacterial survival.

Flea Beetle, is a small (less than ¼ inch long), oval-shaped, metallic blue or green in color, jumping beetle of the leaf beetle family (Chrysomelidae).
 
Damage: Flea beetle feeding produces shot-hole damage on blueberry foliage and is often clustered on terminals.Large numbers of flea beetles can completely defoliate large areas in blueberry fields. Flea beetle larvae feed on blueberry leaves and blossoms from mid-May through June. Adults feed on plant foliage beginning late June or early July.
 
Insecticides: Insecticides recommended for spotted wing drosophila control are also effective against flea beetle, so additional applications for flea beetle management are not necessary if these products are in use. Effective products include:  Assail 30SG, Asana XL 0.66EC, Admire Pro 4.6F, Entrust SC, Entrust 80W.

Gypsy moth is a periodically problematic pest in the Northeast.  Out breaks occur when drought conditions persist throughout the summer, reducing populations of fungal and viral pathogens that prey on the larvae.  

Description and life cycle Flightless gypsy moth females emerge from pupation and lay eggs along the same surface in the late summer early fall (pictured in photo gallery).  Egg masses survive the winter surrounded by a biege wooly mass. Damage occurs when insufficient water is present to allow the microorganisms that can feed on the larvae to multiply to effective population levels. Larvae balloon from egg mass sites and can land and feed on host foliage, reducing pytosynthetic capacity which is especially problematic for young trees.  Larvae will also feed on young fruitlets.    

Monitoring and management While pheromone lures for gypsy moth do exist, they do not help with determining best management timing as they only trap adults which do not feed. To determine best manageemnt time, scout for small larvae moving into the orchard.  The smaller the larvea the more effective the treatment. When targeting early larval instars softer materials are sufficient for maximum efficvacy.

Grape root borer (GRB): Potentially the most destructive insect attacking grape vines. GRB are clearwing moths that resemble wasps. The forewings are dark and the hind wings are more transparent. The adult moths are reddish-brown with thin yellow banding along the abdomens. Male moths are about 5/8 in and females about 3/4 in. The larvae are 1-1/2 in long, cylindrical, cream-colored, and when mature and have a retractable brown head. The larvae spend approximately 2 years feeding in the roots. During the summer of the second year, larvae will pupate near the soil surface before emerging as adults.
 
Damage:
GRB larvae bore into the roots and crown below the soil surface. Because damage is restricted to below ground, problems often go unnoticed until vine decline is observed. Symptoms of GRB attack include poor vine growth and fruit set, even loss of some vines. 
 
Insecticides: Currently only a single insecticide is registered, Lorsban 4E, which has a 35 day preharvest interval. Apply as drench to the base of the vine early to mid-summer.

Alternaria bunch rot typically occurs on ripe or nearly ripe grape bunches, producing brown to black mycelia on the berry surface. It is also occasionally found to be associated with disordered rachis and pedicel. 

It is caused by the fungus Alternaria spp., which is generally considered a opportunistic pathogen of grapes that takes advantage of damaged fruit. Damages from insects, splitting, or primary diseases such as Botrytis fruit rot and sour rot may facilitate Alternaria infection. In contrast, this fungus is more capable of directly infecting during grape withering. Protection of fruit from damage should be the primary defense against Alternaria bunch rot.

Anthracnose of grape, also known as birds eye rot, can damage all succulent parts of the plant. This disease is often seen in rainy, humid, and warm regions. Lesions on shoots and berries are the most common, and symptoms on shoots appear as sunken lesions outlined by a dark ring. Leaf spots appear similarly and the center of these lesions may eventually rot through the leaf, leaving a hole. On berries, small reddish to gray lesions develop with dark margins.

The fungus Elsinoe ampelina causes this disease, infecting shoots after an extended period of leaf wetness. The fungus can spread by splashing rain and can overwinter on infected shoots. Disease management methods include sanitation, resistant cultivars, canopy management, and fungicides.

Bitter rot is a disease that occurs on berries near harvest, which starts as a slight discoloration and advances with concentric growth of fungal spore structures and shriveling. Symptoms closely resemble black rot and ripe rot. The bitter taste from infected fruit is highly characteristic of this disease, and a small amount of infected fruit can make wine undrinkable.

This diseases is caused by Greeneria uvicola, synonymous with Melanconium fuligineum which is favored by warm, wet, and humid weather. Inoculum can come from berry mummies from previous seasons, and can be spread by splashing rain.

Control methods include canopy management, sanitation, and effective fungicides applied at proper timing.

Botrytis bunch rot is a common disease caused by Botrytis cinerea. Although less commonly, this pathogen can damage flowers, leaves, and stems as well.

Botrytis bunch rot occurs after varaison as fruit is nearing harvest, with fruit turning brown (barely visible on reds) at first followed by the production of gray, velvety spores. Sporulating fruit can infect adjacent fruit, and spores dispersed by wind can cause epidemic in entire vinyard. The fungus overwinters as sclerotia in berry mummies or as dormant mycelium in plant debris.

The control relies on the use of fungicides.

Phomopsis cane and leaf spot is a disease that reduces photosynthesis, causes poor fruit development, can cause brittle canes, and can even cause a fruit rot near harvest.

The disease mostly appears as spots or lesions on leaves and shoots. On shoots, the spots start out small and black, then grow along the stem longitudinally, eventually leading to cracking. On leaves, the disease initiates as small, light-green spots which eventually turn black with a yellow margin.

This disease is caused by the fungus, Phomopsis viticola, which is favored by warm, wet conditions. The fungus overwinters on infected plant tissue, producing spore structures that can release spores when splashed with rain.

Management methods include promoting air circulation and sun-exposure, pruning and destroying infected canes, and foliar fungicide applications.

Ripe rot is a bunch rot that occurs late in the season, similar in timing and appearance to bitter rot. Berries infected with ripe rot initially show brown water-soaked spots, followed by the concentric growth of fungal structures on the berry surface, and lastly shriveling.

This disease can be caused by multiple fungal species within the genus Colletotrichum. The fungus can overwinter in mummified fruit, then in the following season it can spread by splashing rain.

Management methods for this disease include sanitation, pruning, and fungicides.

Sour rot is a fruit rot that discolors and softens fruit and accumulates acetic acid, which smells like vinegar. Sour rot develops after veraison and may be aided by tight clusters.

Multiple organisms are associated with this disease including acetic acid producing bacteria, yeasts, fungi, and fruit flies. Fruit flies which feed on damaged fruit are thought to be a major contributor to this disease, therefore avoiding damage to fruit and controlling fruit fly are effective management options.

Spider mites: (e.g. Tetranychus urticae Koch) is a native pest species of mite, which can be found on nearly any broad-leaf plant. It is usually a yellow-green color, with two dark spots flanking the abdomen. The females are around 1/60than inch long with a rounded end to the abdomen, while males are smaller (about 1/80than inch) with a more pointed abdominal tip.

Damage: Mite damage is primarily foliage based. Damage to leaves appears as a general bronzing and mottling of the leaf, as the mites puncture and ingest the contents (including the green chlorophyll) of the plant cells. Spider mites also construct webs, which can be extensive in heavily infested trees. 

Insecticides: The primary means of control are covered during the two (2) applications of horticultural oils during the dormant/delayed-dormant period for targeting scale. If needed, targeted Summer applications of miticides can be used as needed. The preferred choices are curative miticides (e.g. Acramite, Nexter, or Envidor) used in rotation.

Avoid over-application of pyrethroids in the summer/fall, as these sprays have a tremendous impact on predatory mites, while minimal long-term impact on two-spotted spider mite populations.

Flies in the family Syrphidae are commonly known as syrphid flies, hoverflies, or flower flies.  Numerous adult hoverflies are considered mimics of stinging wasps and bees, but these flies are unable to bite or sting. Adult hoverflies are frequently abundant on flowers, which are used as mating sites and food sources. Hoverfly larvae feed on aphids, scale insects, and thrips, and are considered extremely beneficial since each larva is capable of consuming hundreds of aphids during its development.

Lady beetles, also known as lady bird beetles or ladybugs, are among the most visible and best known beneficial predatory insects. Most lady beetles in North America are beneficial as both adults and larvae, feeding primarily on aphids and other small, soft-bodied organisms such as mites, small insects, and insect eggs. The larvae are often dark gray with orange markings and are alligator-like in shape with three pairs of prominent legs. Lady beetle adults are characteristically usually red or orange with black markings, but some species are black, often with red markings.

As adults, green and brown lacewing, are soft-bodied, elongated insects with four membranous (lace-like) wings. these natural enemies are important predators of many types of soft bodied insects and insect eggs. Adults of some species of green lacewing are predaceous, whereas others feed primarily on honeydew, nectar, and pollen. Similarly, brown lacewing adults are also predaceous. Larvae of both groups of lacewing prey upon a wide variety of small insects including mealybugs, psyllids, thrips, mites, whiteflies, aphids, small caterpillars, leafhoppers, and insect eggs.
Minute pirate bugs, or insidious flower bugs, are a group of predaceous insects in the family, Anthocoridae.

Predatory stink bugs are generalist predators where adults and nymphs have long, pointed beaks with which they use to stab their prey and feed. Like pest stink bugs, when threatened they secrete a defensive chemical with a disagreeable smell, hence “stink bugs.” Predatory stink bugs are considered beneficial because they prey on a variety of plant-damaging bugs, beetles, and caterpillars.
 
The spined soldier bug is the most common predatory stink bug in North America and ranges from Mexico to Canada. They are shield-shaped, mottled brown with prominent spines on the "shoulders,” and a distinctive dark line on the membranous tip of each forewing.
 
The Florida predatory stink bug is primarily a Neotropical species that ranges within the southeastern region of the United States. The adults are metallic blue-black with brightly colored orange spots.
 
Predatory stink bugs are highly susceptible to broad-spectrum insecticides, particularly organophosphates and carbamates. They are also susceptible to other broad-spectrum insecticides, such as pyrethroids and neonicotinoids.

Peach rust is caused by Tanzschelia discolor, which causes twig cankers and lesions on leaves and fruit of peach.

Infectious spores (urediniospores) originate from overwintering peach rust pustules on leaves or twig cankers and spread via wind or rain splash.

Chemical Control is typically not needed every year. But if the disease caused problems the previous season, use FRAC 3 or 11 products in early cover sprays or when first symptoms appear.

Non-chemical Control is difficult and focused on scouting to prevent unnecessary applications.

Overview: Henbit (Lamium amplexicaule) is commonly found in strawberry planting holes and row middles.  Henbit is a winter annual which germinates in the fall and grows through the winter and flowers in the spring.  Henbit is a member of the mint family with square stems, opposite leaves that are circular to heart shaped with toothed margins and hairs on the upper leaf surface.  Young leaves occur on petioles while upper leaves are attached directly to the stem.  Henbit may be confused with purple deadnettle (Lamium purpureum) which has triangular shaped leaves that always occur on petioles.   

In the strawberry bed, flumioxazin, sulfentrazone, or oxyfluorfen can be applied preplant to the preformed bed for henbit control.  No postemergence herbicides are registered for application in the bed. The only option in the bed after planting strawberries is hand removal.

Overview: Blackmargined aphid form part of the yellow aphid complex with yellow pecan aphid. As nymphs it is hard to distinguish between the two species as both are pale yellow in color but can exhibit black markings depending on the time of the year and developmental stage. The most noticeable difference between the two is found in the adult stage where blackmargined aphids, as their name suggest, have a heavy black margin along the front edge of the front wings and on the edge of the head and thorax. In addition, the wings are held flat above the body in contrast to the yellow pecan aphid adult that holds its wings gable-like above the body. The cornicles of this species are reduced to pores.

Damage: Blackmargined aphid damage leaves by excreting honey dew onto the foliage as they feed giving the leaf a glossy look. Honeydew can promote of growth of sooty mold fungi which reduces the amount the sunlight that reaches the photosynthetic cells of the leaves. In addition, blackmargined aphids feed on the leaves vascular system with heavy infestations leading to reduced chlorophyll and leaflet size. Severe spring and summer infestations can lead to defoliation.  

Control: In early to mid-season insecticides application should be kept to a minimum. Instead, beneficial insects such as lady beetles and lacewings should be relied on to control pests during this time. If insecticides are used, it is best to avoid using pyrethroids. Due to their quick reproduction and growth, aphids should be scouted for weekly in order to identify infestations and time spraying. To reduce to risk of resistance development, chemical classes should be rotated between treatments. Always be sure to contact your local county extension office for information.

<![endif]--><!--StartFragment--><br /><strong><span style="color:#333333">Tarnished plant bug (TPB)</span></strong><span style="color:#333333"> is one of the first insect pests to potentially require management in the orchard.  Damage is caused by both feeding and oviposition. Depressions in the fruit form around where feeding occurred although this tends to be less damaging than oviposition which causes deep punctures most often near the calyx end of the fruit.  </span><br /><br /><span style="color:#333333"><strong>Description and life cycle</strong> TPB is a small mottled brown bug with a head that stick out just beyond its body, it overwinters in its adult form, hiding under leaf litter. They emerge and move into orchards to feed and lay eggs at the base of flower buds. Populations are highest in orchards during white bud and bloom periods.<br /><br /><strong>Management and monitoring</strong> White sticky cards hung in lower branches (2-3 feet above ground), beginning at bud burst, are most commonly used to monitor for adults. When 3 bugs are observed per trap by green cluster of 4 bugs by white bud, a pre-bloom insecticide may be necessary.  Managing nearby host reservoirs in the fall can reduce population density in the spring. Mowing of host areas in spring can encourage TPB to move into orchards.</span><br /><!--EndFragment-->

Black cherry aphid Myzus cerasi is found wherever cherries are grown but prefers sweet cherry. It infests foliage and leaves honeydew on leaves and fruit. Heavy populations can deform shoots, stunting young trees.

Damage results when heavy infestation causes stunted, curling foliage, and small fruit as well as the honeydew mess.

Monitoring should begin shortly after bud break. There is no treatment threshold, but signs of infestation should be treated promtly as once leaves curl the aphids become difficult to control (by early summer).

Management consists of conserving predators and a delayed dormant oil application, as well as insecticide application if pre-bloom scouting suggests a problem.

<![endif]--><!--StartFragment--><br /><strong><span style="color:#333333">Wooly apple aphid (WAA)</span></strong><span style="color:#333333"> feeds on both subterranean and aerial portions of apple trees. When aerial colonies are present near harvest, the aphids can aggregate on fruit, usually near the stem end, leaving an unappealing “ashy” appearance on the surface. Root systems are generally where the most serious damage occurs as feeding causes gall-like swollen nodes on roots (pictured in photo gallery) and causes root death. Aerial colony infestations of pruning cuts and other wounds can prevent those wounds from healing leaving openings for opportunistic fungi, and other pathogens, to invade.  </span><br /><br /><span style="color:#333333"><strong>Description and life cycle</strong> WAA overwinters on apple, and elm where present, as eggs and early instar nymphs. Nymphs and adults exude a white, waxy, stringy substance that protects the soft bodied insect colonies beneath. These waxy secretions can make insecticide applications less effective. In larger, more standard sized trees, WAA colonies can be found in a higher density deeper into the canopy, making them more difficult to find and manage in a timely fashion.   </span><br /> <br /><strong>Monitoring and management</strong> Early season visual scouting for newly developed aerial colonies, especially on pruning cuts, will indicate that this pest has become active. Make insecticide treatments before the protective wooly mass has developed for best efficacy. Maintain open canopies to increase spray penetration. Limit use of pyrethroids and organophosphates as these can cause population outbreaks as these materials are prone to resistance development and harm natural aphid predators. <br /> <br /><!--EndFragment--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>

Overview: The pecan nut casebearer adult is about a third of an inch long and is brownish gray in color. It can be distinguish from other moths of similar size and color by the ridge of dark scales extending through the middle of its forewings. As larvae, they are often half of an inch long and are olive green to dark green in color with heads that are yellowish brown. The eggs are white and flat when newly laid, but will turn pink and eventually red as they near hatching.
 
Damage: The female casebearer will lay eggs directly on the nut often hiding them in crevices in or under the crown. After hatching the larvae will enter the nut through the stem and feed on the inside of the nut hollowing it out. Early season larvae (later May to early June) will often eat through an entire cluster before completing development while later season larvae will often complete development within a single nut. Larvae will pupate in the damaged nut (which is often dark brown at this point) and emerge as adults 10 days later. Larvae that overwinter will also tunnel into and feed on the shoots of the tree.
 
Control: Pheromone-baited traps are available in order to monitor pecan nut casebearer populations in orchards and to help forecast larval infestation. The treatment spray window is very small as treatment must be applied soon after hatching in order to kill newly emerged casebearers. Once inside the pecan nut, larvae are often safe from insecticide applications. Therefore, scouting should be done regularly as soon as adults are captured in order to locate and identify eggs and larvae. Eggs should be scouted for 7-10 days after first adult capture. Larvae will often enter the nut at 14-20 days after this point. Control should be directed primarily at the early season larvae as they are likely to cause the most damage. Later season generations are often of least concern and are not treated for. Always contact your local extension office in order to receive the most up to date information including local pest severity and proper insecticides to use. See the Trade Names and Active Ingredient sections in this Mobile App to obtain recommended insecticidal materials.
 
References:
University of Georgia Pecan Growers’ Handbook
Oklahoma State University Extension Website
Nobel Research Institute

Overview:  Vetch can be easily controlled with Stinger (clopyralid) postemergence.  Stinger registration in strawberry is issued on a state by state basis; therefore, it may not be registered for use in your state.   Do not add a surfactant or apply in combination with other pesticides or crop injury may occur.  Do not compost treated vegetation if compost will be used on sensitive plants.

Spotted Wing Drosophila (Drosophila suzukii), SWD, is a recently introduced new species of fruit fly in the United States. It was first found on cherries on the U.S. west coast in 2008, but has rapidly colonized many fruit producing regions of the country.

While fruit flies (or vinegar flies) are nothing new in the US, this species is different in its ability to infest healthy fruit. Other species typically infest over-ripe or damaged fruit. Females of this species have serrated ovipositors that can cut into healthy fruit to insert eggs. This can lead to problems with deteriorating fruit in the field or with customers who find multitudes of larvae in fruit after harvest. Cherries, being an early ripening fruit, are attractive to SWD.

Adapted from http://ag.umass.edu/fruit/resources/spotted-wing-drosophila

Overview: The pecan leaf scorch mite is a tetranychid mite or spider mite which has a minute, light green, oval body with a dark green spot on each side and a smaller bright red spot on each “shoulder” as an adult. 
 
Damage: Feeding pecan leaf scorch mite group causes leaflets to have a scorched appearance and ultimately leads to early leaf drop. Mite damage appears as bronzed, scorched areas on the undersides of leaflets. Scorched areas begin at the leaflet midribs then spread out toward leaflet margins. Mites often build up on low limbs in the shaded, interior portions of trees then spread rapidly up and out. For heavy infestations, repeat the application in 5-7 days.
 
Control: Pecan trees should be scouted for mites weekly from late June until harvest.  If a damaging population occurs, a suitable miticide should be applied to the foliage.  Certain insecticides labeled for fruit pest control cause resurgence of pecan leaf scorch mites. In particular, carbaryl and pyrethroid insecticides should be avoided unless absolutely required for late-season weevil control. 

Other Notes on Control:
Savey is an ovicide and should be tank-mixed with an adulticide. Zeal is primarily an ovicide/larvicide.
If abamectin is applied (Agri-Mek), a non-ionic surfactant or horticultural oil MUST be added to the tank.
The products that work for pecan leaf scorch mites can be used for other mite pests in pecans such as leaf roll mites and other spider mites.

Overview: The hickory shuckworm, Cydia caryana (Fitch), is a native pest distributed throughout most of the pecan growing region from South Carolina in the east to Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas in the west.  As the name implies, the hickory shuckworm is also found on several species of hickory.  It has also been reported on black walnut. 

Damage: The hickory shuckworm begins attacking when the nuts are first formed in early June and continues until harvest.  Damage by the hickory shuckworm results from the feeding activity of the larvae.  Prior to shell-hardening, the feeding of shuckworm larvae within the nut results in premature nut drop.  After shell hardening, larvae are confined to feeding within the shuck.  Damage resulting from the shuckmining activities of the larvae include poor kernel development (due to the severing of vascular tissue in the shuck), shuck sticking, scarring and discoloration of the shell and delayed nut maturity.  Except for premature nut drop, shuckworm damage usually goes unnoticed unless the shuck is cut open to reveal the tunneling of the larva within the shuck. 

Monitoring and Control: Scouting for hickory shuckworm is examining dropped nuts for the characteristic whitish residue around the entry hole in June and July. Orchards with a history of shuckworm problems should be treated at shell-hardening, as mature nuts will not drop.  If orchards have a history of shuckworm infestation, a spray should be applied in early June. In early August, 2-3 additional sprays should be applied. Initiate August sprays at half-shell hardening and repeat at 2-week intervals until shuck split if shuckworm activity continues. Chlorpyrifos and pyrethroids (Asana, Ambush, Mustang, etc.) applied for other pests will also control shuckworm. It is not necessary to spray in August if pecan weevil controls are applied.

Overview: The two species of spittlebug which feed on pecan stems, Clastoptera obtusa Say and C. achatina Say, are easily and readily recognized by the frothy, white, foam spittle masses which cover the nymphs in the spring and early summer. 

Damage: Although spittlebugs are considered a pest in certain commercial pecan orchards, there is little direct evidence of economic damage in well-managed orchards. 
 
Control: Controls are not necessary in most years. Definite thresholds have not been established and treatment is seldom needed. However, foliar-applied systemic aphicides provide effective control when desired.
 
Source:
UGA Southeastern Pecan Growers’ Handbook

Overview:

Pecan Leaf Phylloxera
     Pecan leaf phylloxera, Phylloxera notabilis Pergande, is a tiny aphid-like insect that feeds on foliage of immature nursery and orchard trees. The insects are rarely seen because of their small size. It is primarily a pest on seedlings and grafting rootstocks in nurseries and immature saplings growing wild. The first generation of galls are not usually found on mature trees, but second generation galls are sometimes found on secondary growth of heavily fertilized mature pecan trees later in the season, when such growth occurs, but they are not economically important. 
Damage: Feeding by pecan leaf phylloxera causes rapid and abnormal growth of the succulent leaf tissues. The abnormal tissue growth rapidly surrounds and encloses the phylloxeran and is known as a phylloxera gall. Galls caused by pecan leaf phylloxera are prominent wart or tumor-like growths and are similar in appearance. 
 
Pecan (Stem) Phylloxera
    These species of phylloxerans can attack foliage, shoots and fruit of pecans. The adults and nymphs are small, 0.1 to 0.2 inch (2.5-5 mm) ling, soft-bodied, cream-colored aphid-like insects without chronicles. They are rarely seen without the aid of a hand lens. 
Damage: Hard swelling or tumor like galls, one tenth to one inch in diameter, appear on leaves, leafstalks, succulent shoots, catkins, and nuts of new growth. Heavy infestations can completely destroy an entire nut crop and the accompanying malformed and weakened, infested shoots reduce tree vitality and to such an extent that damage may reduce the following years production. 

Control:
Spray trees infested the previous year and surrounding trees during the period from bud break until new growth reaches about one inch in length.  Time sprays with bud break of the earliest cultivars.  A second application 10 - 14 days after the first may be required where the pest has caused heavy or severe damage in the past unless a systemic aphicide is used.

Marssonina Leaf and Fruit Blotch is caused by the fungus Marssonina coronaria, which infects apple leaves and fruit, and is especially devastating in organic orchards with apple scab resistant cultivars.

Infectious spores in spring are disseminated by rain and wind from fallen leaves on the orchard floor where fungus overwinters and which were infected in the previous growing season. Infections start probably sometimes from the second half of May and through first or second week of June.

Sanitation aims to degrade leaf litter on the orchard floor as the main inoculum source by promoting natural and mechanical decomposition of leaves in fall, late winter or early spring. Apply urea or lime and/or flail mow to reduce primary inoculum from leaf litter. Prune the tree crown to facilitate good air circulation.

Chemical control is effective but no fungicides are currently labeled for managing Marssonina Leaf and Fruit Blotch of apple in the USA. Fungicides should be started from petal fall or first cover and continued until harvest. Please read section "More" in the menu above with fungicide efficacy data from other countries.

Blossom Blast of Apple is caused by ice nucleating strains of bacterium Pseudomonas syringae pv. syringae, which can infect undeveloped apple flower buds (half-inch green to pink bud), flowers and leaf clusters and cause their wilting and drooping with papery dry appearance. Blossom blast can advance into twigs but at a very limited fashion. It is primarily know on pear, but can affect apple and can reduce fruit set.

Bacteria survive and grow on the surface of various plants and are favored by cool and wet weather. It is disemminated on apple by rain and insects and some strains act as ice-nucleation particles thus leading to frost injury at near frost temperatures. Outbreaks of blossom blast on apple are associated with frosts or near frost events in spring because frost causes injury to green apple tissue allowing this bacterium to enter and infect.

Chemical control can be achieved by a delayed-dormant copper spray followed by one to two streptomycin sprays applied during bloom, although, these must be applied pre-frost by anticipating predicted frost events based on weather forecast. Once blossom blast is visible, none of these spray materials will help in disease management, however, further spread of this disease cannot occur due to warmer weather after bloom that does not favor the bacterium.

<![endif]--><!--StartFragment--><br /><strong><span style="color:#333333">Apple Maggot Fly (AMF), </span></strong><em><span style="color:#333333">Rhagoletis pomonella:</span></em><span style="color:#333333"> Female flies lay eggs just below the skin of the apple where larvae hatch, feed and burrow into the fruit. This feeding leaves brown trails through the fruit. Oviposition scars are very difficult to identify unless the fruit has been heavily damaged such as one would see in an abandoned orchard.  </span><br /><br /><span style="color:#333333"><strong>Description and life cycle.</strong> AMF has one generation per year. This pest overwinters as a pupa in the soil, usually in abandoned orchards or other unsprayed apple trees. Adults emerge in mid-summer and migrate into commercial orchards. Once adults have emerged, they feed and mate. Females lay eggs 10-14 days after emergence. Once hatched, larvae can feed for up to 4 weeks before dropping to the soil to pupate and overwinter. While the peak emergence and greatest risk of damage is mid-summer, flies can continue to emerge and cause fresh damage into October. <br /><br /><strong>Monitoring and management.</strong> A number of different traps may be used to monitor AMF. All rely on a sticky material to capture curious adults. Most commonly used traps are red spheres coated in "tangle foot", a gooey sticky substance, and are often paired with a commercially available five-component lure. This lure increases the number of flies trapped. When using a lure, the action threshold is an average of 5 flies per trap. When no lure is used, the action threshold is an average of two flies per trap.  Clean traps off prior to insecticide application, any flies caught for a week following an insecticide application should be dismissed. Beyond that week, new applications may be needed if threshold is reached again.   </span><br /><!--EndFragment-->

Obliquebanded leafroller (OBLR) Choristonuera rosaceana feeds on a broad range of hosts plants. Overwintered OBLR larvae feed on developing shoots, leaves and fruits. Young fruits that are damaged by these larvae either abort before maturity, or, can remain on the trees but are grossly deformed. This latter damage is indistinguishable from that caused by green fruit worm feeding. Summer generation larvae feed on foliage and ripening fruits. Fruit feeding leaves the surface pitted with shallow tunneling. This generation, unchecked, can cause damage at harvest that may not show up until later, in storage.   

Description and life cycle 
Adult moths are light beige, often tinged pink with tan to chocolate colored bands running across the width of their bodies. Larvae are yellowish green to olive green with head capsules varying from light brown to black, with many possible shades between. Adult females are approximately 24mm (.94 inches) in length (tip to tail). Males are smaller, measuring approximately 20 mm (.79 inches) in length. Obliquebanded leafroller (OBLR) overwinters as second or third instar larvae wrapped in close fitting cocoons (hibernacula). In the spring, these larvae leave their hibernacula and feed on opening buds. OBLR pupates at the feeding site. This lasts from 10 to 12 days. Adults emerge around mid-June. Adults mate and eggs are laid on leaves shortly thereafter. Once larvae hatch, they move to new leaves to feed and eventually pupate.  Adults emerge in late August, mate, and lay eggs. The subsequent larvae from this egg laying will overwinter as second or third instar larvae.

Monitoring and management 
Scout for larval shelters from tight cluster to Petal Fall. Examine 10 bud clusters per tree for OBLR larvae and apply Bacillus thuringiensis, kurstaki insecticide if more than 3% of clisters examined are infested. Monitor OBLR adults with pheromone traps and use a degree-day developmental model to time insecticide sprays against hatching larvae. Thinning of fruit and pruning water sprouts in midsummer is helpful in reducing fruit damage. Pre-bloom applications, in time with tight-cluster of apple, of materials containing Bacillus thuringiensis, kurstaki (DiPel, Javelin, etc.) may be used to reduce populations of larvae when they are still small. Pre-bloom applications should only be considered when OBLR damage has been historically high. When making petal fall insecticide applications, be sure to choose a material that is effective against larger OBLR larvae, Bt is not effective against larger larvae. Time insecticide applications to target summer generation larvae, not adults. Use trap capture information to determine best timing of Bt for newly emerging larvae and other materials for later instar larvae. Apply insecticide starting at 360 DD (base 43F) after 1st adult trap capture. This pest may require 2-3 sprays 10-14 days apart.

Plum curculio  (PC) is generally considered the single most destructive insect pest in orchards. The most recognizable type of wound caused by PC is the half-moon scar, produced by ovipositing females. Prior to depositing her egg, the female first uses her mouthparts to cut a small crescent-shaped flap in the fruit skin; then, she turns around to deposit an egg. When eggs hatch, larvae tunnel into fruitlets and begin to feed. Larvae complete four instars inside the fruit in about 16 days. PC-infested fruitlets generally drop to the ground prematurely. When an egg is not viable, or a female cuts into a fruit but does not deposit an egg, the scar remains and can be seen at harvest, often making the fruit unmarketable.

Botryosphaeria canker is characterized by wedged-shaped discoloration and necrosis in either the trunk or cordon of grapevines. The cankers are caused by an infection from a fungus in the family Botryosphaeriaceae. The infection can occur on young grapevines, but symptoms may not show up until infected vines are 5 to 7 years old. The primary mode of infection of these pathogenic fungi is entry through a wound, which is often mediated by water. Thus, management of the disease involves strategic pruning to avoid times of high sporulation and wet weather. It is advisable to prune late in the season to avoid peak fungi spore production as well as greater vine susceptibility. If any diseased plant material is identified, it is imperative that it is removed from the vineyard to prevent future transmission of Botryosphaeria canker. Chemical control is helpful when retraining vines and making large trunk or cordon cuts.

Eutypa Dieback is caused by the fungus Eutypa lata and is characterized by canker formation on the primary trunk of grapevines. Cankers appear as flattened areas on the trunk with dark discoloration under the bark. Disease symptoms become apparent in vines of at least five years of age or older and are observed in the vasculature directly above the canker. Physiological changes like smaller leaves and chlorosis are seen along the shoots of diseased plants. These symptoms are most obvious in spring. The primary route of infection is through fresh wounds caused by pruning. Management of E. lata includes the limitation of cultural practices during wet time periods as well as the removal of all infected plant material from the vineyard. Fungicide use may be of benefit, but it needs to be done immediately (within 24 hours) after final dormant pruning.

Phomopsis dieback is caused by the pathogenic fungi, Phomopsis viticola, which is responsible for canker formation in the trunks and cordons of grapevines. The cankers manifest as wedge-shaped regions of dark, necrotic, woody tissue at the site of infection. The symptoms result in decreased vine vigor and yield due to the girdling effect of the dieback in the trunk of the vine. In addition, P. viticola may cause separate infections of the shoot and leaves (see Phomopsis cane and leaf spot), which are characterized by brown lesions on the shoots and light green spots on the foliage. The pathogen is able to persist on old diseased plant material and produce spores. Thus, it is important to excise all symptomatic plant material from the vine and properly discard it from the vineyard. The risk of infection by the spores is greatly increased in the presence of water. As a result, control of P. viticola is centered around limiting cultural practices that result in wounding, especially prior to wet weather conditions.

Esca infection is caused by a complex of pathogenic fungi. Phaeoacremonium aleophilum and Phaeomoniella chlamydospora are the species most commonly identified as the causative agents of infection. Esca infections have distinct symptoms that manifest in both the foliage and trunks of grapevines. Foliar symptoms, including interveinal leaf necrosis that appears red or yellow, are most prevalent during summer. They are often restricted to a single shoot or to shoots originating from the same spur or cane. Spore production and release in the presence of water is the primary method of transmission of the pathogen. Once in contact with fresh wounds, the spores are able to germinate and cause the harmful symptoms observed in the foliage and vasculature of diseased grapevines. Thus, it is important to limit all injurious practices prior to wet weather and remove all diseased plant material from the vineyard. These control measures are the most effective method to limit future infections of healthy vines. Chemical measures to control Esca are difficult, as traditional spray techniques do not penetrate grapevine cuttings sufficiently to control pathogens inhibiting the vascular system.

Crown Gall Disease is most commonly characterized by large abnormal growths at the graft-union known as galls. The gall formation is initiated through infection by Agrobacterium vitis and subsequent manipulation of the vine’s hormonal response. Galls can result in a girdling effect by cutting off nutrient and water transport to aerial parts of the vine. Infected vines may experience lowered fitness and yields. Infection can occur at any site of injury, thus reducing damage caused by freezing or mechanical pruning is vital in disease prevention. A. vitis is able to persist on plant material for years in the soil. Therefore, removing infected plant material can limit the pathogens ability to survive and can decrease the risk of future infection. No-chemicals are truly effective. Antibiotics and copper are effective only against surface galls, and will not control bacteria that are systemically established in the vine.
